title: Notes by the Way; or, what I saw in my rambles
author: Higginson, H. Talbot.
snippet: It is a fine building, forming three parts of a square. At the top of Frederick Street is North Queen Street, where the barracks for foot and cavalry soldiers are situated. High Street is a broad fine street, running from the quays up to Castle Place, and one of the busiest thoroughfares in the city, having splendid shops on each side ; and off it, facing Corn Market, is Lombard Street, where the famous Lombard Temperance Cafe' is situated.

title: Brought to Bay; or, Experiences of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: Very soon we were tramping off towards the West End in hope of getting a sight of " The Prince," and with some curiosity to learn the particular business which took him there. We got as far as Frederick Street, when M'Sweeny suddenly exclaimed—

title: The novels and tales of Robert Louis Stevenson.
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: From 1864 to 1867 Stevenson's education was conducted chiefly at Mr. Thomson's private school in Frederick Street, Edinburgh, and by private tutors in various places to which he travelled for his own or his parents' health. These travels included frequent visits to such Scottish health resorts as Bridge of Allan, Dunoon, Rothesay, North Berwick, Lasswade, and Peebles, and occasional excursions with his father on his nearer professional rounds to the Scottish coasts and lighthouses, as well as several longer journeys to the south of England or the Continent.

title: Nelly Armstrong: a story of the day. By the author of “Rose Douglas” [i.e. S. R. Whitehead]
author: Armstrong, Nelly.
snippet: A young woman, not over-weU clad for the season, and carrying a baby in her arms, which she was endeavouring to screen from the wind, was feebly walking up the west side of Frederick Street, where the gardens separate Queen Street from Heriot Row. She was evidently fearful of attracting observation, for she started at every footstep

title: Nelly Armstrong: a story of the day. By the author of “Rose Douglas” [i.e. S. R. Whitehead]
author: Armstrong, Nelly.
snippet: She was now again in Frederick Street, creeping faintly on in the shade of the trees. She no longer looked at the people who passed her; she was hopeless of succour from them.

title: Notes by the Way; or, what I saw in my rambles
author: Higginson, H. Talbot.
snippet: The York Street Mill is well worth a visit. Further down, York Street is intersected by Frederick Street, in which is situated the Royal Hospital, which I attended when Dr. (now Sir) William MacCormac was house surgeon. It is a fine building, forming three parts of a square.
